page.title: List of Nuttall mountains in England and Wales

revision.text:
{{short description||Peaks above 2,000 ft with 15 m prominence, in England and Wales}} {{See also|Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles}} {{Infobox mountain | name = Nuttall | photo = Pillar Rock from Robinson's Cairn.jpg | photo_caption= [[Pillar (Lake District)#Pillar Rock|Pillar Rock]] in the [[Lake District National Park]] is the only Nuttall that requires ropes to climb.{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/PillarRock.htm|title=Pillar Rock|publisher=HillBaggingUK|quote=Pillar Rock, qualifying as a separate summit to [[Pillar (Lake District)]] itself in the Nuttalls and other lists [the Birketts], is the bane of summit baggers everywhere. Wainwright says that, to walkers "Pillar Rock is positively out of bounds. Don't even try to get a foothold on it". It's graded as a "moderate" rock climb.}} | elevation = over {{convert|2000|ft|1|abbr=on}} | prominence = over {{convert|15|m|1|abbr=on}} | listing = | location = {{Plain list | 446 England & Wales ** 257 [[England]] ** 189 [[Wales]]}} | range = | topo = }} This is a '''list of Nuttall mountains in England and Wales by height'''. [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Nuttalls|Nuttalls]] are defined as peaks above {{convert|2000|ft|1}} in height, the general requirement to be called a [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Elevation|"mountain"]] in the British Isles, and with a [[Topographic prominence|prominence]] above {{convert|15|m|1}}; a mix of [[imperial measures|imperial]] and [[metric system|metric]] thresholds.{{cite web|url=https://www.hill-bagging.co.uk/Nuttalls.php|title=The Nuttalls|publisher=HillBaggingUK|date=2018|quote=The definition of a Nuttall is "any summit of 2000ft (610m) or more which rises above its surroundings on all sides by at least 50ft (15m)". [...] There are currently 446 Nuttalls: 257 in England and 189 in Wales.}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/database_notes.html|publisher=[[DoBIH]]|title=Database Notes|author=Chris Crocker|date=|quote=Nuttalls: Hills in England and Wales at least 2000 feet high with a drop of at least 15 metres on all sides, as published in The Mountains of England and Wales. The list includes 128 summits that do not qualify as Hewitts. Particularly notable is Pillar Rock as its ascent by the easiest route is a Moderate rock climb or Grade 3 scramble. [...] Outside Scotland, the Hewitts (Hills in England, Wales and Ireland over Two Thousand feet high), together with the Nuttalls in England and Wales, are the most accurate and up–to–date of a succession of publications listing the 2,000–foot summits.}} The Nuttall classification was suggested by Anne and John Nuttall in their 1990 two–volume book, "The Mountains of England and Wales".{{cite book | last=Nuttall | first=John & Anne | title=The Mountains of England & Wales - Volume 1: Wales | edition=1st | year=1990 | publisher=Cicerone | location=Milnthorpe, Cumbria | isbn=978-1852845940}} {{cite book | last=Nuttall | first=John & Anne | title=The Mountains of England & Wales - Volume 2: England | edition=1st | year=1990 | publisher=Cicerone | location=Milnthorpe, Cumbria | isbn=978-1852845896}} The list was updated with subsequent revised editions by the Nuttalls.{{cite book| last=Nuttall| first=John & Anne| title=The Mountains of England & Wales – Volume 1: Wales| edition= 3rd| year=2009| publisher=Cicerone| location=Milnthorpe, Cumbria| isbn=978-1852845940}}{{cite book| last=Nuttall| first=John & Anne| title=The Mountains of England & Wales – Volume 2: England| edition= 3rd| year=2008| publisher=Cicerone| location=Milnthorpe, Cumbria| isbn=978-1852845896}} Because of the prominence threshold of only {{convert|15|m|1}}, the list is subject to ongoing revisions.{{cite web|url=https://www.ukhillwalking.com/articles/features/going_nuts_for_nuttalls_-_the_2000ft_peaks_of_england+wales-8951|title=Going Nuts for Nuttalls - the 2000ft Peaks of England & Wales|publisher=UKHillWalking|author=Myrddyn Phillips|quote=Numbering several hundred summits, the Nuttalls - the 2000-foot peaks of England and Wales - are a classic tick list. In this age of accurate mapping you might assume the list was definitive, but in fact many entries have been added or demoted over the years. The most recent changes have been made only this month. Myrddyn Phillips, one of the surveyors responsible for several revisions, takes us through the additions and deletions.}} In response, Alan Dawson introduced the [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Hewitts|Hewitts]], with a higher prominence threshold of {{convert|30|m|1}}.{{cite book| last=Dawson |first=Alan |year=1992 |title=The Relative Hills of Britain |url=http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/marilyns/ |publisher=Cicerone Press |location=Milnthorpe |isbn=1-85284-068-4 |deadurl=yes| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100921045806/http://bubl.ac.uk/org/tacit/marilyns/ |archivedate=2010-09-21 |df= }} This was the prominence threshold that the [[UIAA]] set down in 1994 for an "independent" peak.{{cite web|url=https://www.theuiaa.org/mountaineering/mountain-classification/|title=MOUNTAIN CLASSIFICATION|publisher=[[UIAA]]|date=March 1994|quote=}} In 2010, Dawson replaced his Hewitts with the fully "metric" [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Simms|Simms]], consisting of a height threshold of {{convert|600|m|1}}, and a prominence threshold of {{convert|30|m|1}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.hills-database.co.uk/database_notes.html|title=Database Notes: Hewitts|publisher=[[Database of British and Irish Hills]]|author=Chris Crocker|quote=In June 2010 Dawson created the Simms (Six–hundred Metre Mountains; originally called Sims) by combining the Murdos, Corbett Tops, Graham Tops and Hewitts and lowering the height threshold to 600m. [...] Hewitts are Hills in England, Wales and Ireland at least 2000 feet high with a drop of at least 30 metres on all sides. Although subsumed into the Simms, the list has been retained by its author.}} However, both the Nuttall and Hewitt classifications have become popular with [[peak bagging|peak baggers]], and both remain in use, and their respective authors maintain up to date lists, as does the ''[[Database of British and Irish Hills]].'' {{as of| October 2018}} there were 446 Nuttalls, with 257 in England and 189 in Wales.{{efn|name="windy"|[[Windy Gyle]] is classed by the DoBIH as being "ES", which means on the border of England and Scotland, however their website, Hill Bagging, counts [[Windy Gale]] as an English Nuttall}} The first people registered as climbing all of the Nuttalls were Anne and John Nuttall themselves, in March 1990. A register of people who declare they have climbed all of the Nuttalls is kept by the [[Long Distance Walkers Association]] ("LWDA"); {{as of | October 2018}}, it totalled 302 names.{{efn|A separate mark of ''NRP'' (Not [[Pillar (Lake District)#Pillar Rock|Pillar Rock]]) is noted for climbers who decide not to undertake the rock-climbing needed to summit Pillar Rock}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nuttalls.com/mountains/completers.shtml|title=Completers|publisher=Nuttalls.com|author1=Anne Nuttall|author2=John Nuttall|date=September 2018}} On 16 September 2017, James Forrest completed all 446 Nuttalls in six months.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/the-filter/meet-part-time-mountaineer-conquered-446-peaks-six-months/|title=Meet the part–time mountaineer who conquered 446 peaks in six months|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=8 October 2017 | quote= But on September 16, Forrest's successful ascent of Scafell Pike completed the challenge and secured him the record. He did it in precisely six months, enough to make him faster than any of the 292 people who did it before him. The challenge is known in the hiking world as "the Nuttalls".}} ==Coverage of Nuttalls== The table below of 257 English Nuttals at October 2018, include: {{ordered list|type=lower-roman | All 180 of the [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Hewitts|Hewitts]] in England (by definition, a Hewitt is a Nuttall); | 51 of the 175 [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Marilyns|Marilyn]] mountains and hills in England; | All 4 of the 120 [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#P600s (the "Majors")|P600]] mountains in the British Isles that are English (by definition, a P600 is a Nuttall). }} The table below of 189 Welsh Nuttals at October 2018, include: {{ordered list|type=lower-roman | All 135 of the [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Hewitts|Hewitts]] in Wales (by definition, a Hewitt is a Nuttall); | 53 of the 158 [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Marilyns|Marilyn]] mountains and hills in Wales; | All 8 of the 120 [[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#P600s (the "Majors")|P600]] mountains in the British Isles that are Welsh (by definition, a P600 is a Nuttall). }} ==Nuttall mountains in England by height== Data is from the ''[[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles#Database of British and Irish Hills|Database of British and Irish Hills]]'' ("DoBIH") in October 2018, and are peaks DoBIH marks as English ("E" and "ES"), and Nuttalls ("N").{{efn|name="dobih"}} John and Anne Nuttall update the list of Nuttalls from time to time, and the DoBIH also updates their measurements as more surveys are recorded, so these tables should not be amended or updated unless the entire DoBIH data is re-downloaded again. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left" |- |+ style="text-align: left;" |Nuttals in England, ranked by height (DoBIH, October 2018) |- !style="text-align:left"|[[Elevation|Height]] Rank !style="text-align:left"|[[Topographic prominence|Prom.]] Rank !style="text-align:left"|Name !style="text-align:left"|Parent Name{{efn|name="parent"|In the [[DoBIH]], this is the "Parent (Ma)" code, which the DoBIH define as follows: "The hill number and name of the parent Marilyn of lower prominence hills. In the Excel and csv versions the hill's own number is given for hills that are parents (there are no parents of parents) and '0' indicates a non-Marilyn with no parent. Thus a filter or sort on this column will return a parent (usually first) and all its children."}} !style="text-align:left"|Map Sec. !style="text-align:left"|Area (Nuttalls){{efn|name="area"|In the [[DoBIH]], this is a special DoBIH column that is used to match, as best as possible, the terms given in specific books on mountains, namely the Munros, the Wainwrights and the Nuttalls.}} !style="text-align:left"|County !style="text-align:left"|[[Summit|Height]] (m) !style="text-align:left"|[[Topographic prominence|Prom.]] (m) !style="text-align:left"|[[Summit|Height]] (ft) !style="text-align:left"|[[Topographic prominence|Prom.]] (ft) !style="text-align:left"|[[Topographic map|Topo Map]] !style="text-align:left"|[[Ordnance Survey National Grid|OS Grid Reference]] !style="text-align:left"|[[Lists of mountains and hills in the British Isles|Classification]]

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic_links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:PermaLink/772743896#Future_of_magic_links|local RfC]] - [[User:PrimeBOT/13|BRFA]]
revision.text:
{{for|data relating to SSSIs in this Area of Search|List of SSSIs in Powys}} [[File:Montgomery AOS.png|thumb|{{legend|#BF97BF|Montgomery AOS}}]] [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest|SSSIs]] in the UK are [[SSSI notification|notified]] using the concept of an [[Area of Search]] (AOS), an area of between {{convert|400|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and {{convert|4000|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in size.<ref>Joint Nature Conservation Committee (1998 revision); ''Guidelines for the Selection of Biological SSSIs'', section 4.11, p. 17. {{ISBN|1873701721}}.</ref> The Areas of Search were conceived and developed between 1975 and 1979 by the [[Nature Conservancy Council]] (NCC), based on regions created by the [[Local Government Act 1972]].<ref>Joint Nature Conservation Committee (1998 revision); ''Guidelines for the Selection of Biological SSSIs'', section 4.5, pp. 14–15. {{ISBN|1873701721}}.</ref> Whereas England had its Areas of Search based on 46 counties, those in Wales were based on a combination of the counties and smaller districts. In 1974, Wales was divided into 8 counties, with 37 [[Districts of Wales|districts]]. The NCC created 12 Welsh Areas of Search; they mostly follow county borders, but the larger counties ([[Dyfed]], [[Powys]] and [[Gwynedd]]) were divided into multiple Areas using district borders. [[Mid Glamorgan|Mid]] and [[South Glamorgan]] were merged into a single AOS, whilst [[Llanelli (district)|Llanelli district]] was included in the [[West Glamorgan]] AOS.
Due to subsequent local government reorganisation in the UK since 1972, many counties and districts have been divided, merged or renamed. Using the AOS system alone would make it difficult to search for individual SSSI citations via the [[Countryside Council for Wales]] (CCW) database without knowing 1972 region divisions. As a result, the CCW groups Welsh SSSIs using the [[Local government in Wales|subdivisions of Wales]] formed in April 1996 by the [[Local Government (Wales) Act 1994]], resulting in 22 [[Principal areas#Wales|principal areas]].
Montgomery AOS lies within the county of Powys.
For SSSIs elsewhere in the UK, see [[List of SSSIs by Area of Search]].
==See also== *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Powys]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{SSSI AOS lists}}
[[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Montgomery| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Montgomery]]

page.title: List of glaciers in South America

revision.comment: /* Venezuela */ update, all glaciers in Venezuela are gone, except for the Humboldt glacier, see Braund & Bezada (2013) ( doi:10.1353/lag.2013.0. )
revision.text:
[[Image:Laguna San Rafael.jpg|right|thumb|[[San Rafael Glacier]], [[Chile]].]] [[Image:Perito Moreno Glacier - Satelite - NASA - ISS004-E-9707.JPG|right|thumb|[[Perito Moreno Glacier]], [[Argentina]] as seen from space.]] [[Image:Pastoruri Glacier.jpg|right|thumb|[[Pastoruri Glacier]], [[Peru]].]] [[Image:Laguna Glaciar Bolivia.png|right|thumb|[[Glacier Lagoon]], [[Bolivia]].]]
Glaciers in South America develop exclusively on the [[Andes]] and are subject to the Andes various climatic regimes namely the [[Tropical Andes]], [[Dry Andes]] and the [[Wet Andes]]. Apart from this there is a wide range of altitudes on which glaciers develop from 5000 m in the [[Altiplano]] [[mountains]] and [[volcanoes]] to reaching sealevel as tidewater glaciers from [[San Rafael Lagoon]] (45° S) and southwards. South America hosts two large [[ice field]]s, the [[Northern Patagonian Ice Field|Northern]] and [[Southern Patagonian Ice Field]]s, of which the second is the largest contiguous body of glaciers in extrapolar regions. By surface about 80% of South America's glaciers lie in [[Chile]].

page.title: List of mountains in the Philippines

revision.text:
{{Redirect|Mountains of the Philippines|lists of Philippine [[volcano]]es by type|List of volcanoes in the Philippines}} The following is a '''partial list of mountains in the [[Philippines]]''. Several of these are [[List of volcanoes in the Philippines|volcanoes]], formed by [[subduction|subducting]] [[tectonic plate]]s surrounding the [[archipelago]].{{cite web|title=PHIVOLCS Volcano Monitoring|url=http://www.phivolcs.dost.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=50&Itemid=86|website=Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology|accessdate=14 November 2015|date=9 May 2008}}
File:Ph_mtpulag.jpg|[[Mount Pulag|Pulag]], highest in [[Luzon]] File:Dulang-dulang_peak.JPG|[[Mount Dulang-dulang|Dulang-dulang]], Philippine's 2nd highest File:The Ring of Mt. Apo.jpg|[[Mount Apo|Apo]] is the highest in [[Mindanao]] and all of the Philippines File:Mount_Canlaon.JPG|[[Kanlaon Volcano|Kanlaon]], highest in the [[Visayas]] File:Mt.Mayon_tam3rd.jpg|[[Mayon Volcano|Mayon]], highest in the {{nowrap|[[Bicol Region]]}}
==List== {{GeoGroup}} [[File:Relief Map Of The Philippines.png|thumb|upright=0.8|
Terrain of the Philippines
]] This list contains most of the highest [[mountain]]s in the country. It is limited to mountain [[Summit (topography)|peaks]] with, if known, an elevation of at least {{convert|200|m|abbr=off}} [[above sea level]], and may include those considered as [[hill]]s. The distinction between a hill and a mountain in terms of elevation is unclear and largely subjective, but a hill is universally considered to be less tall and less steep than a mountain.{{cite web|title=Hill|url=http://education.nationalgeographic.com/encyclopedia/hill/|website=[[National Geographic Society]]|accessdate=14 November 2015|quote=Hills are easier to climb than mountains. They are less steep and not as high. But, like a mountain, a hill will usually have an obvious summit, which is its highest point.}} * ''Name'': mountains are sorted according to ''only name''s (without the "Mount" prefix) for easier reference in name and spelling variants. Unnamed peaks are ''italicized''. ''(note: to minimize clutter, citations for names are limited only to mountains with [[Variant name (geography)|variant name]]s, spellings, and/or those that currently do not have elevation data)'' * ''Elevation'': sorted in meters above sea level ''(note: Some mountains may contain several different elevations that may conflict with each other. Each of these are supported by their own provided sources)''. * ''Province(s) covered'': Some mountains are situated within two or more provinces borders. "Lanao" and "Davao" entries, which were derived from the [[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology]] website, are ''italicized'' since they are no longer provinces. * ''Coordinates'': sorted according to [[latitude]]. Several of these (most especially volcanoes) were provided by the [[Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology|PHIVOLCS]] website). Others were derived mostly from the [[OpenStreetMap|OpenStreetMap (OSM)]] database ''(released under the [[Open Database License]])'', and a few from [[GeoNames]] ''(released under the [[Creative Commons]] attribution license)''. * ''Notes'': if a volcano, may contain the [[Volcano#Volcanic activity|type]], as classified by the PHIVOLCS.

The Ragay coast is hilly and rolling. Mt. Isarog with an elevation of 1, 976 meters and Mt. Iriga with 1, 196 meters, in the central and southern parts are inactive volcanoes. Also there is the Tangkong Baka mountain range which is the lower portion of the Sierra Madre mountain system and the Calinigan Mountain Range (904 meters) in the Partido area. Other mountains in the province are: Mt. Sugutin- 366m, Mt. Tiis- 610 m, Saddle Peak- 1,028m, Triple Peak- 638m, Mt. Putianay- 640m, Mt. Elizario- 508m, Mt. Talitig- 385m.}}

revision.text:
A list of [[tree]] species, grouped generally by [[Ecozone|biogeographic realm]] and specifically by [[Ecozone#Bioregions|bioregions]], and [[shade tolerance]]. '''Shade-tolerant species''' are species that are able to thrive in the [[Shade (shadow)|shade]], and in the presence of natural competition by other plants. '''Shade-intolerant species''' require full [[sunlight]] and little or no competition. '''Intermediate shade-tolerant''' trees fall somewhere in between the two. {{Expand list|date=May 2009}}
==[[Americas]]== ===[[Nearctic ecozone]]=== ====Eastern North America==== '''Shade tolerant''' * ''[[Abies balsamea]]'', Balsam Fir * ''[[Acer negundo]]'', Boxelder * ''[[Acer saccharum]]'', Sugar Maple * ''[[Aesculus|Aesculus spp.]]'', Buckeyes * ''[[Chamaecyparis thyoides]]'', Atlantic White Cypress or Atlantic White Cedar * ''[[Cornus florida]]'', Flowering Dogwood * ''[[Persimmon|Diospyros spp.]]'', Persimmon * ''[[Fagus grandifolia]]'', American Beech * ''[[Ilex opaca]]'', American Holly * ''[[Ostrya virginiana]]'', Eastern Hophornbeam * ''[[Picea glauca]]'', White Spruce * ''[[Picea mariana]]'', Black Spruce * ''[[Picea rubens]]'', Red Spruce * ''[[Tilia americana]]'', Basswood * ''[[Thuja occidentalis]]'', Northern White Cedar * ''[[Morus rubra]]'', Red Mulberry * ''[[Carpinus caroliniana]]'', American Hornbeam * ''[[Magnolia grandiflora]]'', Southern Magnolia * ''[[Tsuga canadensis]]'', Eastern Hemlock * ''[[Tupelo|Nyssa spp.]]'', Tupelos * ''[[Carya laciniosa]]'', Shellbark Hickory <ref>{{cite book|title=Best Management Practices - Agroforestry Series Volume 1: Woodlot Management|date=2007|publisher=Ontario Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs|location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada|page=15|edition=18E}}</ref>
'''Intermediate shade tolerant''' * ''[[Acer rubrum]]'', Red Maple <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/acerub/all.html|title=Acer rubrum|website=www.fs.fed.us|access-date=2018-01-26}}</ref> * ''[[Acer saccharinum]]'', Silver Maple * ''[[Betula lenta]]'', Sweet Birch * ''[[Castanea dentata]]'', American Chestnut * ''[[Celtis occidentalis]]'', Hackberry * ''[[Fraxinus americana]]'', White Ash * ''[[Fraxinus pennsylvanica]]'', Green Ash * ''[[Fraxinus nigra]]'', Black Ash * ''[[Magnolia|Magnolia spp.]]'', Magnolias * ''[[Quercus alba]]'', White Oak * ''[[Quercus macrocarpa]]'', Bur Oak * ''[[Quercus nigra]]'', Water Oak * ''[[Quercus rubra]]'', Northern Red Oak * ''[[Slash Pine|Pinus elliottii]]'', Slash Pine * ''[[Eastern White Pine|Pinus strobus]]'', Eastern White Pine * ''[[Taxodium distichum]]'', Bald Cypress * ''[[Ulmus americana]]'', American Elm * ''[[Ulmus thomasii]]'', Rock Elm * ''[[Betula alleghaniensis]]'', Yellow Birch * ''[[Hickory|Carya spp.]]'', Hickories (except for Shellbark)
'''Shade intolerant''' * ''[[Betula papyrifera]]'', Paper Birch * ''[[Betula populifolia]]'', Gray Birch * ''[[Catalpa|Catalpa spp.]]'', Catalpas * ''[[Pecan|Carya illinoinensis]]'', Pecan * ''[[Kentucky Coffeetree|Gymnocladus dioicus]]'', Kentucky Coffee Tree * ''[[Juglans cinerea]]'', Butternut * ''[[Juglans nigra]]'', Black Walnut * ''[[Juniperus virginiana]]'', Eastern Red Cedar * ''[[Tamarack Larch|Larix laricina]]'', Tamarack * ''[[Liriodendron tulipifera]]'', Yellow poplar * ''[[Maclura pomifera]]'', Osage Orange * ''[[Pinus banksiana]]'', Jack Pine * ''[[Pinus echinata]]'', Shortleaf Pine * ''[[Longleaf Pine|Pinus palustris]]'', Longleaf Pine * ''[[Red Pine|Pinus resinosa]]'', Red Pine * ''[[Pitch Pine|Pinus rigida]]'', Pitch Pine * ''[[Pinus taeda]]'', Loblolly pine * ''[[Virginia Pine|Pinus virginiana]]'', Virginia Pine * ''[[Platanus occidentalis]]'', Sycamore * ''[[Populus deltoides]]'', Eastern Cottonwood * ''[[Populus grandidentata]]'', Big-Tooth Aspen * ''[[Populus tremuloides]]'', Quaking Aspen * ''[[Prunus pensylvanica]]'', Pin Cherry * ''[[Prunus serotina]]'', Black Cherry * ''[[Robinia pseudoacacia]]'', Black Locust * ''[[Willow|Salix spp.]]'', Willows * ''[[Sassafras|Sassafras spp.]]'', Sassafras
====Western North America==== '''Shade tolerant''' * ''[[Abies amabilis]]'', Pacific Silver Fir * ''[[Abies concolor]]'', White Fir * ''[[Abies grandis]]'', Grand Fir * ''[[Abies lasiocarpa]]'', Alpine Fir * ''[[Acer circinatum]]'', Vine Maple * ''[[Acer macrophyllum]]'', Big-leaf Maple * ''[[Arbutus arizonica]]'', Arizona Madrone * ''[[Pacific Madrone|Arbutus menziesii]]'', Pacific Madrone * ''[[Texas Madrone|Arbutus xalapensis]]'', Texas Madrone * ''[[Cupressus nootkatensis]]'', Nootka Cypress * ''[[Calocedrus decurrens]]'', California Incense-cedar * ''[[Notholithocarpus densiflorus]]'', Tan Oak * ''[[Picea engelmannii]]'', Engelmann Spruce * ''[[Picea sitchensis]]'', Sitka Spruce * ''[[Quercus chrysolepis]]'', Canyon Live Oak * ''[[Sebastiania pavoniana]]'', Mexican jumping bean<ref name="Hilje">{{cite journal |last1=Hilje |first1=Branko |last2=Calvo-Alvarado |first2=Julio |last3=Jiménez-Rodríguez |first3=César |last4=Sánchez-Azofeifa |first4=Arturo |title=Tree species composition, breeding systems, and pollination and dispersal syndromes in three forest successional stages in a tropical dry forest in Mesoamerica |journal=Tropical Conservation Science |date=23 March 2015 |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=76–94 |doi=10.1177/194008291500800109 |language=English |issn=1940-0829 |oclc=5807396390}}</ref> * ''[[Sequoia sempervirens]]'', Coast Redwood * ''[[Sequoiadendron giganteum]]'', Giant Sequoia * ''[[Taxus brevifolia]]'', Pacific Yew * ''[[Thuja plicata]]'' Western Red Cedar * ''[[Torreya californica]]'', California Torreya * ''[[Tsuga heterophylla]]'', Western Hemlock * ''[[Tsuga mertensiana]]'', Mountain Hemlock * ''[[Umbellularia californica]]'', California Laurel
'''Intermediate shade tolerant''' * ''[[Red Fir|Abies magnifica]]'', Red Fir * ''[[Alnus rubra]]'', Red Alder * ''[[Cercis canadensis]]'', Texas Redbud * ''[[Chrysolepis|Chrysolepis spp.]]'', Golden Chinquapin * ''[[Fraxinus latifolia]]'', Oregon Ash * ''[[Juniperus ashei]]'', Ashe Juniper * ''[[Picea pungens]]'', Colorado Blue spruce * ''[[Prunus mexicana]]'', Mexican Plum * ''[[Sugar Pine|Pinus lambertiana]]'', Sugar Pine * ''[[Western White Pine|Pinus monticola]]'' Western White Pine * ''[[Pinus radiata]]'', Monterey Pine * ''[[Douglas-fir|Pseudotsuga spp.]]'', Douglas-fir * ''[[Quercus garryana]]'', Oregon White Oak * ''[[Quercus lobata]]'', valley oak
'''Shade intolerant''' * ''[[Abies procera]]'', Noble Fir * ''[[Juniperus californica]]'', California Juniper * ''[[Juniperus deppeana]]'', Alligator Juniper * ''[[Juniperus monosperma]]'', One-seed Juniper * ''[[Juniperus occidentalis]]'', Western Juniper * ''[[Juniperus osteosperma]]'', Utah Juniper * ''[[Juniperus scopulorum]]'', Rocky Mountain Juniper * ''[[Subalpine Larch|Larix lyallii]]'', Alpine Larch * ''[[Western Larch|Larix occidentalis]]'', Western Larch * ''[[Whitebark Pine|Pinus albicaulis]]'', Whitebark Pine * ''[[Pinus aristata]]'', Rocky Mountains Bristlecone Pine * ''[[Knobcone Pine|Pinus attenuata]]'', Knobcone Pine * ''[[Foxtail Pine|Pinus balfouriana]]'', Foxtail Pine * ''[[Lodgepole Pine|Pinus contorta]]'', Lodgepole Pine * ''[[Coulter Pine|Pinus coulteri]]'', Coulter Pine * ''[[Limber pine|Pinus flexilis]]'', Limber Pine * ''[[Jeffrey Pine|Pinus jeffreyi]]'', Jeffrey Pine * ''[[Pinus longaeva]]'', Great Basin Bristlecone Pine * ''[[Bishop Pine|Pinus muricata]]'', Bishop Pine * ''[[Ponderosa Pine|Pinus ponderosa]]'', Ponderosa Pine * ''[[Gray Pine|Pinus sabineana]]'', Gray Pine * ''[[Pinyon pine|Pinus Ducampopinus spp.]]'', Piñon Pines * ''[[Fremont cottonwood|Populus fremontii]]'', Fremont Cottonwood * ''[[Populus tremuloides]]'', Quaking aspen
==[[Eurasia]]== ===[[Palearctic ecozone]]=== ====[[Central Europe]]==== '''Shade tolerant''' * ''[[Abies alba]]'', European Silver Fir, especially shade tolerant<ref name="BP">{{Cite book | edition = 2. Aufl. | publisher = Preußisch Geologische Landesanstalt | last = von Linstow | first = O. | title = Bodenanzeigende Pflanzen | location = Berlin | date = 1929 }}</ref> * ''[[Acer platanoides]]'', Norway Maple * ''[[Acer pseudoplatanus]]'', Sycamore Maple * ''[[Carpinus betulus]]'', European Hornbeam * ''[[Fagus sylvatica]]'', European Beech, especially shade tolerant<ref name="BP"></ref> * ''[[Ilex aquifolium]]'', European Holly * ''[[Ostrya carpinifolia]]'', European Hop-Hornbeam * ''[[Prunus avium]]'', Wild Cherry * ''[[Sorbus domestica]]'', True Service Tree * ''[[Sorbus torminalis]]'', Wild Service Tree * ''[[Taxus baccata]]'', European Yew, especially shade tolerant<ref name="BP"></ref> * ''[[Ulmus glabra]]'', Wych Elm * ''[[Ulmus laevis]]'', European White Elm
'''Intermediate shade tolerant''' * ''[[Acer campestre]]'', Field Maple * ''[[Acer monspessulanum]]'', Montpellier Maple * ''[[Acer opalus]]'', Italian Maple * ''[[Alnus glutinosa]]'', Black Alder * ''[[Alnus incana]]'', Grey Alder * ''[[Castanea sativa]]'', Sweet Chestnut * ''[[Fraxinus excelsior]]'', European Ash * ''[[Fraxinus ornus]]'', Manna Ash * ''[[Juglans regia]]'', Common Walnut * ''[[Mespilus germanica]]'', Common Medlar * ''[[Picea abies]]'', Norway Spruce * ''[[Pinus cembra]]'', Swiss Pine * ''[[Prunus padus]]'', Bird Cherry * ''[[Pyrus pyraster]]'', European Wild Pear * ''[[Quercus cerris]]'', Turkey Oak * ''[[Quercus petraea]]'', Sessile Oak * ''[[Sorbus aria]]'', Whitebeam * ''[[Sorbus aucuparia]]'', European Rowan * ''[[Sorbus intermedia]]'', Swedish Whitebeam * ''[[Tilia cordata]]'', Small-leafed Linden * ''[[Tilia platyphyllos]]'', Large-leafed Linden<ref>Linden trees are sometimes regarded as shade-tolerant and sometimes as light-loving. Two German papers claim that light requirements of ''Tilia platyphyllos'' are greater than of ''Tilia cordata'' and that they change with climate, age of the tree and soil quality: [http://www.waldwissen.net/wald/naturschutz/arten/wsl_seba/wsl_seba_linden.pdf] [http://www.wald-in-not.de/download13/linde.pdf]</ref> * ''[[Ulmus minor]]'', Field Elm
'''Shade intolerant''' * ''[[Betula pendula]]'', Silver Birch, especially high light requirement * ''[[Betula pubescens]]'', Downy Birch * ''[[Juniperus communis]]'', Common Juniper * ''[[Larix decidua]]'', European Larch, especially high light requirement * ''[[Malus sylvestris]]'', European Crab Apple * ''[[Pinus mugo]]'', Mountain Pine * ''[[Pinus nigra]]'', European Black Pine * ''[[Pinus sylvestris]]'', Scots Pine * ''[[Populus alba]]'', Silver Poplar * ''[[Populus nigra]]'', Black Poplar * ''[[Populus tremula]]'', Aspen * ''[[Quercus pubescens]]'', Downy Oak * ''[[Quercus robur]]'', Pedunculate Oak * ''[[Salix alba]]'', White Willow * ''[[Salix caprea]]'', Goat Willow * ''[[Salix fragilis]]'', Crack Willow
==External links== {{Portal|Trees}} *[http://forest.wisc.edu/sites/default/files/pdfs/publications/79.pdf Tolerance of Tree Species] *[http://www.na.fs.fed.us/spfo/pubs/silvics_manual/table_of_contents.htm Silvics of North America], an encyclopedia of characteristics for around 200 tree species native to the United States published by the [[United States Forest Service]]. *[http://www.utb-shop.de/downloads/dl/file/id/27/zusatzkapitel_zeigerwerte_der_pflanzen_mitteleuropas.pdf Zeigerwerte der Pflanzen Mitteleuropas (German)]

{{Infobox legislation|short_title=''Proposed'' National Energy Guarantee|image=Coat of Arms of Australia.svg|imagesize=150px|caption=[[Coat of Arms of Australia]]|long_title=A proposed act to introduce National Energy Guarantee}}
'''National Energy Guarantee''' ('''NEG''') was an energy policy proposed by the [[Turnbull Government|Turnbull government]] in late 2017 to deal with rising energy prices in Australia and lack of clarity for energy companies to invest in energy infrastructure. The policy specifically targets energy companies in the [[National Electricity Market]] and large energy users to have a reliability obligation as well as emissions reduction obligations.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/oct/18/what-is-the-national-energy-guarantee-explainer|title=What is the national energy guarantee and is it really a game changer?|last=Murphy|first=Katharine|date=2017-10-18 |work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-10-17/explainer-energy-policy-what-is-the-coalitions-new-plan/9057158|title=What is the National Energy Guarantee and what does it mean for consumers? |date=2017-10-17|work=ABC News|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-AU}}</ref>
Turnbull's successor [[Scott Morrison]] announced in September 2018 to focus on cheap [[Electricity retailing|Electricity prices]]; Australia would (also without NEG) make efforts to lower [[Carbon dioxide]] emissions.<ref>[https://www.sbs.com.au/news/neg-dead-morrison-to-ditch-energy-legislation-but-keep-paris-targets '' 'NEG dead': Morrison to ditch energy legislation, but keep Paris targets'']</ref>
== History == {{main|Carbon pricing in Australia}} In the years leading up to the proposed NEG, energy policy in Australia included the Rudd government's proposed [[Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme]], the introduction and repeal of the Gillard government's [[Clean Energy Act 2011]], the Abbott government's [[Emissions Reduction Fund]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.environment.gov.au/climate-change/government/emissions-reduction-fund|title=Emissions Reduction Fund|author=<!--Not stated-->|publisher=Australian Government: Department of the Environment and Energy|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref> and proposals for an Emissions Intensity Scheme (EIS)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/emissions-intensity-scheme-best-and-most-appropriate-policy-new-national-electricity-boss-says-20170526-gwdz9e.html|title=Emissions intensity scheme 'best and most appropriate' policy, new national electricity boss says|last=Hunter|first=Fergus|date=2017-05-26|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en}}</ref> and a Clean Energy Target (CET)<ref name=":failed">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-opinion/out-of-the-ashes-of-failed-attempts-finally-a-chance-to-put-the-climate-wars-behind-us-20171016-gz2ac8.html|title=Out of the ashes of failed attempts, finally a chance to put the climate wars behind us|last=Martin|first=Peter|date=2017-10-17|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-US}}</ref> among others. Throughout this time, energy prices in energy resource rich Australia continued to rise. In October 2017 the Turnbull government announced a new proposal, the National Energy Guarantee,<ref name="pmneg">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pm.gov.au/media/2017-10-17/national-energy-guarantee-deliver-affordable-reliable-electricity|title=National Energy Guarantee to deliver affordable, reliable electricity|author=<!--Not stated-->|publisher=Australian Government: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet|date=2017-10-17|website=www.pm.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref>, intended to "lower electricity prices, make the system more reliable, encourage the right investment and reduce emissions".<ref name="pmneg"/> Subsidies and incentives for renewable energy will be scrapped under the plan.<ref name=":1" /> The Labor opposition argues the plan will destroy the renewables sector,<ref name=":1" /> but the government argues renewables can be competitive without subsidies,<ref name=":1" /> and expects Australia will still meet its [[Paris Agreement]] obligations under the plan.<ref name=":1" /> The [[Climate Council]] called the NEG "a woefully inadequate response" to climate change.<ref name="cc">{{Cite web|url=https://www.climatecouncil.org.au/uploads/a9cc46d55d6b05b957c8dcd32ef436b8.pdf|title=Briefing Paper: What Are Stakeholders Saying About The National Energy Guarantee?|author=<!--Not stated-->|publisher=Climate Council|date=2018|website=www.climatecouncil.org.au |language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref>
=== Politics === The government via the COAG Energy Council meeting on 14 July 2017 established the Energy Security Board to coordinate the implementation of the Finkel Review authored by Australian's Chief Scientist [[Alan Finkel]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.coagenergycouncil.gov.au/publications/establishment-energy-security-board-media-release|title=Establishment of the Energy Security Board Media Release |last=Vaughan|first=Rebecca|date=2017-08-08 |website=www.coagenergycouncil.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> The government decided not to adopt the Clean Energy Target<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cleanenergycouncil.org.au/policy-advocacy/energy-transformation/clean-energy-target.html|title=Clean Energy Council - Clean Energy Target|website=www.cleanenergycouncil.org.au|language=en|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> as recommended by the Finkel Review after coming pressure from the conservative elements<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/oct/20/turnbull-predicts-states-will-sign-up-to-national-energy-guarantee|title=Turnbull predicts states will sign up to national energy guarantee|last=Karp|first=Paul|date=2017-10-20|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-03|last2=Murphy|first2=Katharine|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> of the Liberal Party as well as vocal climate sceptics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-10-10/tony-abbott-says-action-on-climate-change-is-like-killing-goats/9033090|title=Climate change action like trying to 'appease the volcano gods', Abbott says|date=2017-10-10|work=ABC News |access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/tony-abbotts-loopy-climate-change-speech-privately-funded-20171010-gyybi6|title=Tony Abbott's 'loopy' climate change speech privately funded |last=Bourke|first=Latika |date=2017-10-11|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-US}}</ref>
The NEG will need the support of the Australian states signed up to it to activate the scheme.<ref name=":3" /> The reason is the states need to pass legislation to change the functioning of the national electricity market.<ref name=":0" /> Government critics of emission reduction targets are advocating for a "hockey-stick" target, where the most reduction occurs in the years just before 2030.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Murphy |first1=Katharine |title=After a week of political theatrics, the energy wars remind us this drama costs {{!}} Katharine Murphy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jun/02/after-a-week-of-political-theatrics-the-energy-wars-remind-us-this-drama-costs |accessdate=2 June 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=1 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==== Reliability obligation ==== The reliability obligation means that energy companies need to provide a mix of energy generation sources that can be fired up on demand to meet peak loads or emergency demand.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
==== Low Emissions obligation ==== This dictates energy companies need to have in their mix of energy production from low emission sources like gas fired power stations, wind, solar, batteries or hydropower or even coal fired stations.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== Compliance === The government indicated if these regulatory obligations are not met after a period of time, the government can take action such as deregistering non complying energy providers.<ref name=":0" /> The reliability guarantee is going to be setup by<ref name=":2" /> the [[Australian Energy Market Commission]] (AEMC) and [[Australian Energy Market Operator]] (AEMO).
The emissions guarantee will be established by the Commonwealth and overseen by the [[Australian Energy Regulator]] (AER).<ref name=":2" />
== Modelling == In 2017, Federal Energy Minister [[Josh Frydenberg]] asked the Energy Security Board to undertake further modelling to determine the NEG's impact on the national electricity market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://coagenergycouncil.gov.au/publications/national-energy-guarantee-modelling|title=National Energy Guarantee Modelling|last=Mills|first=Chanel|date=2017-10-26|website=coagenergycouncil.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> The minister also forecast in the best scenario, the NEG can deliver price reduction of 6 percent of power bills.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/national-energy-guarantee-would-cut-6-per-cent-off-power-bills-in-best-scenario-20171018-gz37oi|title=National energy guarantee would cut 6 per cent off power bills in best scenario|last=Bagshaw|first=Eryk |date=2017-10-18 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en-US}}</ref> It is equivalent to a average $115 annual savings from 2020 to 2030.<ref name=":4" /> As of July 2018, the underlying assumptions behind the [[Energy Security Board]]'s modelling has not been made public.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mountain |first1=Bruce |title=The National Energy Guarantee is a flagship policy. So why hasn't the modelling been made public? |url=https://theconversation.com/the-national-energy-guarantee-is-a-flagship-policy-so-why-hasnt-the-modelling-been-made-public-100754 |website=The Conversation |language=en}}</ref>

{{short description|Relatively flat submarine region that rises well above the level of the ambient seabed}} [[File:Map showing the location of oceanic plateaus (in green) in the Australia-New Zealand region of the South Pacific.svg|thumb|Map showing the location of oceanic plateaus (in green) in the Australia-New Zealand region of the South Pacific]] An '''oceanic''' or '''submarine plateau''' is a large, relatively flat elevation that is higher than the surrounding relief with one or more relatively steep sides.{{Harvnb|IHO|2013|p=2-12}} There are 184 oceanic plateaus covering an area of {{Convert|18,486,600|km2|abbr=on}}, or about 5.11% of the oceans.{{Harvnb|Harris|Macmillan-Lawler|Rupp|Baker|2014|loc=Plateaus (Supplementary Table 20), p. 16}} The South Pacific region around Australia and New Zealand contains the greatest number of oceanic plateaus (see map). Oceanic plateaus produced by [[large igneous province]]s are often associated with [[Hotspot (geology)|hotspots]], [[mantle plume]]s, and [[volcanic island]]s — such as Iceland, Hawaii, Cape Verde, and Kerguelen. The three largest plateaus, the [[Caribbean large igneous province|Caribbean]], [[Ontong Java Plateau|Ontong Java]], and [[Mid-Pacific Mountains]], are located on [[Swell (geology)|thermal swells]]. Other oceanic plateaus, however, are made of rifted continental crust, for example [[Falkland Plateau]], [[Lord Howe Rise]], and parts of [[Kerguelen Plateau|Kerguelen]], [[Mascarene Plateau|Seychelles]], and Arctic ridges.{{Harvnb|Mooney|Laske|Masters|1998|loc=Anomalous Crust: Oceanic Plateaus, Hotspots, and Rifts, pp. 754–755}} Plateaus formed by large igneous provinces were formed by the equivalent of continental [[flood basalt]]s such as the [[Deccan Traps]] in India and the [[Snake River Plain]] in the United States. In contrast to continental flood basalts, most igneous oceanic plateaus erupt through young and thin ({{Convert|6|-|7|km|abbr=on}}) [[mafic]] or [[ultra-mafic]] crust and are therefore uncontaminated by felsic crust and representative for their mantle sources. These plateaus often rise {{Convert|2|-|3|km|abbr=on}} above the surrounding ocean floor and are more buoyant than oceanic crust. They therefore tend to withstand subduction, more-so when thick and when reaching subduction zones shortly after their formations. As a consequence, they tend to "dock" to continental margins and be preserved as [[Accretion (geology)|accreted]] [[terrane]]s. Such terranes are often better preserved than the exposed parts of continental flood basalts and are therefore a better record of large-scale volcanic eruptions throughout Earth's history. This "docking" also means that oceanic plateaus are important contributors to the growth of continental crust. Their formations often had a dramatic impact on global climate, such as the most recent plateaus formed, the three, large, Cretaceous oceanic plateaus in the Pacific and Indian Ocean: Ontong Java, Kerguelen, and Caribbean.{{Harvnb|Kerr|2013|p=632}} ==Role in crust–mantle recycling== Geologists believe that igneous oceanic plateaus may well represent a stage in the development of [[continental crust]] as they are generally less dense than [[oceanic crust]] while still being denser than normal continental crust. Density differences in crustal material largely arise from different ratios of various elements, especially [[silicon]]. Continental crust has the highest amount of silicon (such rock is called [[felsic]]). Oceanic crust has a smaller amount of silicon ([[mafic]] rock). Igneous oceanic plateaus have a ratio intermediate between continental and oceanic crust, although they are more mafic than felsic. However, when a [[tectonic plate|plate]] carrying oceanic crust [[subduction|subducts]] under a plate carrying an igneous oceanic plateau, the volcanism which erupts on the plateau as the oceanic crust heats up on its descent into the mantle erupts material which is more felsic than the material which makes up the plateau. This represents a step toward creating crust which is increasingly continental in character, being less dense and more buoyant. If an igneous oceanic plateau is subducted underneath another one, or under existing continental crust, the eruptions produced thereby produce material that is yet more felsic, and so on through geologic time. ==List of oceanic plateaus== {| class="wikitable" align="right" with=50% |+ Global distribution of oceanic plateaus{{Harvnb|Harris|Macmillan-Lawler|Rupp|Baker|2014|loc=Supplementary table 20}} |- ! [[File:Chinese - Teapot in the Form of Two Peaches - Walters 491045.jpg|thumb|Chinese - Ceramic teapot in the form of two peaches - a symbol of immortality (or a wish for long life). [[Yixing]]- [I-hsing]-ware, with blue-brown glazing.]] In [[Chinese mythology]], '''Peaches of Immortality'''<ref>also translated as the '''Immortal Peaches''' and '''Magical Peaches'''</ref> ({{zh|c={{linktext|仙桃}}|p={{linktext|xiāntáo}}|cy=sīn tòuh}} or {{zh|c=蟠桃|p=pántáo|cy=pùhn tòuh}}) are consumed by [[xian (Taoism)|the immortals]] due to their mystic virtue of conferring longevity on all who eat them. Peaches symbolizing immortality (or the wish for a long and healthy life) are a common symbol in Chinese art, appearing in depictions or descriptions in a number of fables, paintings, and other forms of art, often in association with thematically similar iconography, such as certain deities or immortals or other symbols of longevity, such as deer or [[Crane in Chinese mythology|cranes]].
==Peach Banquets== [[File:The Immortal Dongfang Shuo Stealing a Peach (東方朔偷桃) silk tapestry.jpg|upright|thumb|Silk tapestry of [[Dongfang Shuo]] stealing a peach of immortality, [[Ming dynasty]] ([[Metropolitan Museum of Art]])]]
The [[Jade Emperor]] and his wife [[Xi Wangmu]] (Queen Mother of the West) ensured the deities' everlasting existence by feasting them with the peaches of immortality. The immortals residing in the palace of Xi Wangmu were said to celebrate an extravagant banquet called the "Feast of Peaches" ({{zh|c=蟠桃會|p=Pántáo Huì|cy=pùhn tòuh wúih}}, or {{zh|c=蟠桃勝會|p=Pántáo Shènghuì|cy=pùhn tòuh sing wúih}}), celebrated on earth in honor (birthday) of Xi Wangmu on the 3rd day of the 3rd moon month. The immortals wait six thousand years before gathering for this magnificent feast; the peach tree put forth leaves once every thousand years and it required another three thousand years for the fruit to ripen. Statues depicting Xi Wangmu's attendants often held three peaches. And the [[Eight Immortals]] crossing the seas to attend the banquet is a popular subject in paintings.
Both the ''[[:zh:漢武故事|Stories of the Emperor Wu]]'' and ''[[:zh:博物志 (張華)|Research into Nature]]'' wrote about an imaginary meeting between the [[Emperor Wu of Han]] and the Queen Mother of the West offering the Peach to him.<ref>{{cite book|author=Michael Loewe|title=Ways to paradise: the Chinese quest for immortality|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oLw0AQAAIAAJ|accessdate=28 June 2011|date=31 December 1994|publisher=SMC Pub.|isbn=978-957-638-183-6|page=95}}</ref>
==''Journey to the West''== It is a major item featured within the popular fantasy novel ''[[Journey to the West]]''. The first time in which these immortal peaches were seen had been within heaven when [[Sun Wukong]] had been stationed as the Protector of the Peaches. As the Protector, Sun quickly realized the legendary effects of the immortal peaches if they were to be consumed – over 3,000 years of life after the consumption of a single peach – and acted quickly as to consume one. However, he ended up running into many fragments of trouble such as a certain queen that was planning on holding a peach banquet for many members of Heaven. He manages to make himself very small and hide within a sacred peach. Later on within the series, he would have another chance to eat an immortal fruit – in which would be his second time. A certain {{convert|1000|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} tree was stationed behind a monastery run by a Taoist master and his disciples- in which the master had been gone. The tree bore 30 of the legendary Man-fruit (fruits that looked just like a new born, complete with sense organs) once every 10,000 years. The man-fruits would grant 360 years of life to one who merely smelled them and 47,000 years of life to one who consumed them. After this point within the novel, these Immortal Peaches would never be seen again.<ref name="Yu1984">{{cite book|author=Anthony C. Yu|title=Journey to the West|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0HGaPH7KHH0C&pg=PA74|year=1984|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-97153-7|page=74}}</ref>
==Others== Members of the [[Eight Immortals]] and the [[Old Man of the South Pole]]<ref>{{cite book|author=Patricia Bjaaland Welch|title=Chinese art: a guide to motifs and visual imagery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5sgO9BuZQSEC&pg=PA159|accessdate=28 June 2011|year=2008|publisher=Tuttle Publishing|isbn=978-0-8048-3864-1|page=159|quote=[Shouxing] commonly holds a giant peach of immortality in his right hand and a walking stick with attached gourd (holding special life-giving elixir) in his left.}}</ref> (a longevity deity) are sometimes depicted carrying a Peach of Immortality.
Because of the stories and the peach's association with long-life, peach is a common decoration (the fruit or an image thereof) on traditional birthday cakes and pastries in China.<ref>{{cite book|author=Frederick J. Simoons|title=Plants of life, plants of death|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KEUAbrBoeBAC&pg=PA268|accessdate=28 June 2011|year=1998|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press|isbn=978-0-299-15904-7|page=268}}</ref>
Another peach-related folktale from East Asia is the [[Momotarō]].
==See also== * [[Ambrosia]], Greek food of immortality * [[Kunlun Mountain (mythology)]], mythological residence of Xi Wangmu; not originally identical with the modern "[[Mount Kunlun]]" * [[Longevity peach]], a pastry representation of Peaches of Immortality * “[[Peach Blossom Spring]]”, a fable of utopia

{{Use British English|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox spaceflight|auto=all | name = Prospero | image = Prospero X-3 model 2012.JPG | image_caption = Flight spare of the Prospero satellite in Science Museum, London. | mission_type = Technology | operator = [[Royal Aircraft Establishment|RAE]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1971-093A | SATCAT = 5580 | mission_duration = | spacecraft_bus = | manufacturer = [[British Aircraft Corporation|BAC]]
[[Marconi Electronic Systems|Marconi]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|66|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|28 October 1971}} | launch_rocket = [[Black Arrow]] R3 | launch_site = [[Woomera Prohibited Area|Woomera]] [[Woomera Launch Area 5|LA-5B]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = 24 January 2015, 04:50:31 UTC{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=5580|title=PROSPERO (BLACK ARROW) Satellite details 1971-093A NORAD 5580|publisher=N2YO|date=24 January 2015|accessdate=25 January 2015}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|7295.54|km|mi}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.053451 | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|534|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|1314|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 82.04 degrees | orbit_period = 103.36 minutes | apsis = gee }} The '''Prospero''' [[satellite]], also known as the '''X-3''',{{cite web |url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/prospero.htm |title=Prospero (X-3) |first=Gunter |last=Krebs |work=Gunter's Space Page |accessdate=22 September 2011}} was launched by the [[United Kingdom]] in 1971. It was designed to undertake a series of experiments to study the effects of [[space environment]] on [[communications satellite]]s and remained operational until 1973, after which it was contacted annually for over 25 years. Although Prospero was the first British satellite to have been launched successfully by a British rocket, the first British satellite placed in orbit was [[Ariel 1]], launched in April 1962 on a U.S. rocket. Prospero has the [[COSPAR]] (NSSC ID) designation 1971-093A and the [[United States Space Command|US Space Command]] satellite catalogue number 05580. ==Construction== Prospero was built by the [[Royal Aircraft Establishment]] in [[Farnborough Airport|Farnborough]]. Initially called [[Puck (Shakespeare)|Puck]], it was designed to conduct experiments to test the technologies necessary for communication satellites, such as [[solar cell]]s, telemetry and power systems. It also carried a [[micrometeoroid]] detector, to measure the presence of very small particles.{{Harvnb|Harvey|2003|p=89}} When the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] cancelled the [[Black Arrow]] programme,{{cite web |title=The Cancellation of Black Arrow |url=http://www.spaceuk.org/ba/blackarrowcancellation.htm| publisher=SpaceUK.org |work=A Vertical Empire |first=C. N. |last=Hill |accessdate=5 November 2011}} the development team decided to continue with the project, but renamed the satellite [[Prospero]] when it was announced it would be the last launch attempt using a British rocket. An earlier Black Arrow launch, carrying the [[Orba X-2]] satellite, had failed to achieve orbit after a premature second-stage shut down.{{Harvnb|Baker|1978|p=230}} ==Launch== Prospero was launched at 04:09 [[GMT]] on 28 October 1971, from [[Woomera Launch Area 5|Launch Area 5B]] (LA-5B) at [[Woomera, South Australia]], on a [[Black Arrow]] rocket, making Britain the [[Timeline of first orbital launches by country|sixth nation]] to place a satellite into orbit using a domestically developed [[carrier rocket]].{{cite book|last1=Norris|first1=Pat|title=Spies in the sky: surveillance satellites in war and peace|date=2008|publisher=Springer|location=Berlin|isbn=9780387716725|page=156}} The Black Arrow's final stage Waxwing rocket also entered orbit, "rather too enthusiastically", as it continued to thrust after separation and collided with Prospero, detaching one of the satellite's four radio antenna.{{Harvnb|King-Hele|2005|p=163}} ==Current status== A [[tape recorder]] is on board, which failed on 24 May 1973 after 730 plays.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} As was noted in an episode of the [[BBC]] television series [[Coast (TV series)|''Coast'']], radio transmissions from Prospero could still be heard on 137.560 MHz in 2004,''Coast'', 26 October 2006, Series 2 Episode 1, BBC though the signals used in the episode would actually come from an [[Orbcomm (satellite)|Orbcomm]] satellite, rather than Prospero itself (as the later Orbcomm used the same 137.560 MHz frequency since Prospero was considered no longer active). Prospero had officially been deactivated in 1996, when the UK's [[Defence Research Establishments|Defence Research Establishment]] decommissioned their satellite tracking station at [[Lasham]], [[Hampshire]], but the satellite had been turned on in past years on its anniversary. It is in a [[low Earth orbit]], and is not expected to decay until about 2070, almost 100 years after its launch. In September 2011 a team at University College London's [[Mullard Space Science Laboratory]] announced plans to re-establish communications with Prospero, in time for the satellite's 40th anniversary. As of September 2012, not much progress had been made in establishing contact with the satellite due to time constraints.{{cite web|last=Roger J A |first=Duthie |title=Long Overdue Update |url=http://blogs.ucl.ac.uk/prospero-satellite/2012/04/04/long-overdue-update/ |publisher=UCL Blogs |accessdate=25 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024215327/http://blogs.ucl.ac.uk/prospero-satellite/2012/04/04/long-overdue-update/ |archivedate=24 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[Timeline of artificial satellites and space probes]] * [[Ariel 1]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|colwidth=33em| refs= {{cite web |title=Plan to revive 1970s UK satellite |first= Richard |last=Hollingham |date=5 September 2011 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14783135 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=5 September 2011}} {{cite episode |title=British Space Race |series=Time Shift |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC Four]]}} }} '''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} * {{citation |last=Baker |first=David |title=The Rocket: The History and Development of Rocket and Missile Technology |year=1978 |publisher=New Cavendish Books |isbn=978-0-904568-10-3}} * {{citation |last=Harvey |first=Brian |title=Europe's Space Programme: To Ariane and Beyond |year=2003 |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-1-85233-722-3}} * {{citation |last=King-Hele |first=Desmond |title=A Tapestry of Orbits |year=2005 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-01732-9}} {{refend}} ==External links== * [http://homepage.powerup.com.au/~woomera/bkarrow.htm Black Arrow] from "Woomera on the Web" * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050206220350/http://www.astronautix.com/craft/prospero.htm Prospero] from Encyclopedia Astronautica * [http://qrg.globaltuners.com/details.php?id=23116 Prospero] in the Global Frequency Database {{Black Arrow}} {{Orbital launches in 1971}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1971]] [[Category:Artificial satellites orbiting Earth]] page.title: Renewable energy in the Cook Islands

revision.text:
The [[Cook Islands]] is a Large Ocean State with an [[Exclusive Economic Zone]] spanning approximately 2 million km2. It extends from latitude 8° to 23° South, longitude 156° to 167° West. The nation is divided into a northern group of six islands and a southern group of nine islands. Three are uninhabited (Suwarrow, Manuae and Takutea). Rarotonga is the most populated island with about 85% of the national population; the outer islands are remote and sparsely populated.
Electrical power has been provided by generators on each island, but diesel fuel is sourced from [[Auckland]] and requires long sea voyages, especially to the northern atolls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://e-po.co.uk/solar-power-for-the-cook-islands/ |title=Solar power for the Cook Islands |publisher=E-PO |date=2014-11-28 |accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref> Faced with global [[climate change]] driven largely by human activities, shipping fuel such long distances no longer seems viable. [[carbon footprint]]. The outer islands conserved fuel by turning the power off overnight (11 pm to 6 am), but because [[Taio]] shipping is rare they occasionally still ran out of fuel. Rarotonga and Manihiki had 24-hour power.
[[New Zealand Government]] decided to assist [[Cook Islands]] by providing solar power in the northern atolls. The AID programme ''Uira Natura ko Tokerau'' (NZ$20 million) was provided by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs & Trade<ref>http://www.mfat.govt.nz</ref> Construction of the solar arrays was by PowerSmart Solar of New Zealand <ref>http://www.powersmartsolar.com</ref>
The first solar site was at [[Rakahanga]], which was completed in September 2014. [[Pukapuka]] and [[Nassau (Cook Islands)|Nassau]] were next, going online at Christmas 2014. Construction began at [[Tongareva]] on 23 February 2015 and just 10 weeks later both villages [[Omoka]] and Te Tautua were running on solar power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://powersmartsolar.co.nz/blog/id/589/Opening_ceremony_in_Cook_Island_News |title=PowerSmart NZ - Solar Electricity, Solar Panels & Solar Systems – Blog |publisher=Powersmartsolar.co.nz |date=2015-05-19 |accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref> [[Manihiki]] was progressed at the same time.<ref>http://www.go100percent.org/cms/index.php?id=70&tx_ttnews[tt_news]=35</ref> In June 2015 all of the northern atolls were fully solar powered. In addition the requirement to send ships north during the ''cyclone season'' (November to April) is now reduced.
The solar arrays [[photovoltaic]] produce 800 volts DC, which is inverted to 230 volts AC and fed to the grid. Power can be inverted again to 48 volts DC to trickle charge the batteries. The system is completed with a small diesel generator that starts automatically.
Construction of solar arrays in the Southern Cook Islands is out for tender,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://infratec.co.nz/news/54-rarotonga-solar-farm-commission |title=Rarotonga solar farm commissioned |publisher=Infratec.co.nz |date=2014-10-15 |accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref> and should be funded by the [[Asian Development Bank]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adb.org/news/adb-help-cook-islands-generate-solar-power |title=ADB to Help Cook Islands Generate Solar Power | Asian Development Bank |publisher=Adb.org |date=2014-11-24 |accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref> it is expected that Cook Islands will be entirely solar powered by 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sprep.org/Climate-Change/cook-islands-100-renewable-energy-by-2020 |title=Cook Islands: 100% Renewable Energy by 2020 | Climate Change |publisher=Sprep.org |date=2011-07-05 |accessdate=2015-06-28}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Portal|Cook Islands|Energy|Renewable energy}} <!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Renewable energy in New Zealand]] [[Category:Energy in the Cook Islands]]

[[File:Refracted wave.png|thumb|Propagating seismic waves (bottom) and related travel time diagram (top) of the direct (blue) and the first refracted phase (green)]] '''Seismic refraction''' is a geophysical principle (see [[refraction]]) governed by [[Snell's Law]]. Used in the fields of [[engineering geology]], [[geotechnical engineering]] and [[exploration geophysics]], [[seismic refraction traverse]]s ([[seismic lines]]) are performed using a [[seismograph]](s) and/or [[geophone]](s), in an array and an energy source. The seismic refraction method utilizes the refraction of seismic waves on geologic layers and rock/soil units in order to characterize the subsurface geologic conditions and [[Structural geology|geologic structure]]. The methods depend on the fact that seismic waves have differing velocities in different types of soil (or rock): in addition, the waves are refracted when they cross the boundary between different types (or conditions) of soil or rock. The methods enable the general soil types and the approximate depth to strata boundaries, or to [[bedrock]], to be determined. ==P-Wave Refraction (a.k.a. Compression Wave Refraction)== P-wave refraction evaluates the [[compression wave]] generated by the seismic source located at a known distance from the array. The wave is generated by vertically striking a striker plate with a sledgehammer, shooting a seismic shotgun into the ground, or detonating an explosive charge in the ground. Since the compression wave is the fastest of the [[body waves|seismic waves]], it is sometimes referred to as the [[primary wave]] and is usually more-readily identifiable within the seismic recording as compared to the other seismic waves. ==S-Wave Refraction (a.k.a. Shear Wave Refraction)== S-wave refraction evaluates the [[shear wave]] generated by the seismic source located at a known distance from the array. The wave is generated by horizontally striking an object on the ground surface to induce the shear wave. Since the shear wave is the second fastest wave, it is sometimes referred to as the [[secondary wave]]. When compared to the compression wave, the shear wave is approximately one-half (but may vary significantly from this estimate) the velocity depending on the medium. == Two Horizontal Layers.== [[File:refraction 2layers.png|800px|center|Two layers model.]] ic0 - critical angle
V0 - velocity of the first layer
V1 - velocity of the second layer
h0 - thickness of the first layer
T01 - intercept

:i_{c_{0}} = asin \left( {V_{0} \over V_{1}} \right) : T = {2h_{0}cos(i_{c_{0}}) \over V_{0}} + {X \over V_{1}} = T0_{1} + {X \over V_{1}} : h_{0}= {T0_{1}V_{0} \over 2cos(i_{c}) } : h_{0} = {X_{cross_{1}} \over 2} \sqrt{{V_{1}-V_{0} \over V_{1} + V_{0}}} == Several Horizontal Layers.==
: h_{n} = {V_{n} \over cos(i_{n})} \left( {T0_{n+1} \over 2} - \sum_{j=0}^{n-1}{h_{j}\sqrt{{1 \over V_{j}^2} - {1 \over V_{j+1}^2}}} \right) ==Inversion methods== * The General Reciprocal method * The [[Plus minus method]] * Refraction inversion modeling (refraction [[tomography]]) * [[Monte Carlo method|Monte Carlo]] simulation * [[Genetic algorithm]]s ==See also== * [[Reflection seismology]] ==References== {{No footnotes|date=April 2009}} * [http://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Publications/EngineerManuals/EM_1110-1-1802.pdf US Army Corp of Engineers EM 1110-1-1802] * [http://www.cflhd.gov/geoTechnical/ Central Federal Lands Highway Division] [[Category:Geophysics]] [[Category:Seismology]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=October 2016}} {{COI|date=October 2016}}}} {{Infobox Organization |name = Student Switch Off |motto = Switch off - save energy - win prizes |formation = 2006 |extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> |type = [[Community interest company]] |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = Carbon reduction |headquarters = Kingston, [[London]] |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = UK |membership = |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = Director |leader_name = Dr. Neil Jennings |parent_organization = <!-- if one --> |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.studentswitchoff.org }}
The '''Student Switch Off''' is a campaign that aims to encourage students to save energy when living in University [[halls of residence]].<ref>{{cite web | title=About Student Switch Off | url=http://www.studentswitchoff.org/about-us|website=Studentswitchoff.org| accessdate=2010-11-09}}</ref> It is run by the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students]].
The campaign currently runs at 35 universities across the UK and 10 Universities across Europe. In the academic year 2016/17, 26,000+ students pledged their support for energy-saving in their halls of residence.
The scheme concentrates on [[behavioural change]] and [[social marketing]] to bring about carbon reduction.<ref>{{cite web | title=Degrees Cooler In Action | url=http://www.nus.org.uk/en/Campaigns/Green-Zone/Degrees-Cooler-Behavioural-Change-in-Action/|website=Nus.org.uk | accessdate=2010-11-09}}</ref>
In May 2012 the campaign won an Ashden Award (described as the Oscars of the energy-saving world) and in March 2011 won the 'Best Energy Saving Idea' award at the inaugural People and Environment Achievement Awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://peaawards.co.uk/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305220003/http://peaawards.co.uk/ |archivedate=2011-03-05 |df= }}</ref>
==History== The campaign was set up by Dr Neil Jennings as a pilot project at the [[University of East Anglia]] in 2006. In the pilot year the campaign helped to reduce energy usage by an average of over 10% in halls of residence – saving around 90 tonnes of {{chem|CO|2}} and over £19,000 in energy expenditure. Neil Jennings received significant support in developing the campaign from the Ben & Jerry's Climate Change College,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.climatechangecollege.org/home.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528163854/http://www.climatechangecollege.org/home.php |archivedate=2010-05-28 |df= }}</ref> and secured sponsorship of the campaign from E.ON, Odeon, The Independent and First.
The campaign expanded to 7 Universities in 2007/08 and 11 in 2008/09 until in 2009 the Student Switch Off partnered with the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)]] as part of the [[Defra]] funded Degrees Cooler project, increasing the numbers of Universities hosting the campaign by 22. Other partners included [[People & Planet]], London Sustainability Exchange, Green Impact and Student Force for Sustainability.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.studentswitchoff.org/about-us/our-history |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422202106/http://www.studentswitchoff.org/about-us/our-history |archivedate=2012-04-22 |df= }}</ref>
In 2009, the Student Switch Off was chosen by Carbon Leapfrog as one of the projects it would support with pro-bono legal and accountancy support.
In 2012 ownership of the campaign was transferred to the National Union of Students and in 2014 the campaign received funding from the EU to expand into four more European countries - Cyprus, Greece, Lithuania and Sweden.
In 2017 the campaign received additional funding from the EU to expand to Bulgaria, Ireland and Romania and to develop advice materials for students living in the private rented sector to reduce their exposure to fuel poverty.
==Results== {| class="wikitable" |- style="text-align:center;" ! Year !! Universities !! No. of Students Signed up !! % electricity reduction !! Tonnes of CO2 Saved !! £ Saved |- style="text-align:center;" | 2006-07|| 1 || 130 || 10% || 90 || £19,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2007-08|| 7 || 2,800 || 8.9% || 550 || £100,000+ |- style="text-align:center;" | 2008-09|| 11 || 4,980 || 9.3% || 1,295 || £218,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2009-10|| 33 || 12,052 || 6.9% || 2,100 || £337,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2010-11|| 37 || 15,351 || 6.9% || 1,522 || £232,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2011-12|| 43 || 19,430 || 5.7% || 1,405 || £220,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2012-13|| 54 || 22,715 || 5.3% || 1,478 || £219,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2013-14|| 54 || 26,812 || 5.9% || 1,606 || £261,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2014-15|| 48 || 26,274 || 5.8% || 1,467 || £269,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2015-16|| 44 || 26,653 || 6.6% || 1,813 || £330,000 |- style="text-align:center;" | 2016-17|| 38 || 26,353 || 5.8% || 1,362 || £255,000 |} N.B. The aggregate CO2 and £ saving is variable between years even with a similar % reduction because of changing prices of energy, changing carbon emissions per kWh of electricity and changing number of months included in the analysis at different Universities.
==Awards== {{Prose|section|date=October 2016}} The Student Switch Off has picked up the following awards since its inception in 2006:
May 2012: Ashden Awards Winner <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ashden.org/winners/studentswitchoff12 |title=Keeping a lid on fuel costs | Ashden Awards, sustainable and renewable energy in the UK and developing world |website=Ashden.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-23}}</ref>
March 2011: Climate Week Awards. Finalist in Best Campaign category <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.climateweek.com/awards/award-categories/best-campaign-in-association-with-tesco/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130119094243/http://www.climateweek.com/awards/award-categories/best-campaign-in-association-with-tesco/ |archivedate=2013-01-19 |df= }} </ref>
March 2011: People and Environment Achievement Awards. Winner, Best Energy Saving Idea
June 2010: National eWell-Being Awards. Highly commended, Energy efficiency category<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ukceed.org/2010/06/28/national-awards-celebrate-the-benefits-of-ict-3/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207201505/http://www.ukceed.org/2010/06/28/national-awards-celebrate-the-benefits-of-ict-3/ |archivedate=2011-02-07 |df= }} </ref>
Nov 2008: The Green Awards. Highly commended, Best Green Campaigner
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} The '''Talalay process''' is a method of producing [[Molding (process)|molded]] pieces of [[latex]] [[foam rubber]]. A liquid latex rubber base is introduced to a closed mold and is then [[vacuum]]ed of air. The mold is then frozen to stabilize the cell structure. [[Carbon dioxide]] gas is introduced and the mold is heated to [[Curing (chemistry)|cure]] the rubber. Leon, Joseph and Anselm Talalay<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mattress1st.com/mattressterms-t.inc |title=Mattress Terms |publisher=Mattress1st.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-11}}</ref> developed the "Talalay" process at various commercial entities. [[Benjamin Goodrich|B.F. Goodrich]] in [[Shelton, Connecticut]], [[Dunlopillo]] in [[Pannal]], [[Harrogate]], UK,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dunlopillo.gr/company.php?lang=en&id=14 |title=Dunlopillo :: Company / Company History |publisher=Dunlopillo.gr |date= |accessdate=2012-02-12}}</ref> and Vita Talalay in [[Maastricht]], [[Netherlands]], made this process commercially practical in the late 1940s. The first Talalay production plants were built in England, Canada and the United States.
==Product== The Talalay process is an elaborate process that yields very controlled densities and product "feel". The formulation uses many of the same base components as the Dunlop formulation, but without [[gel]]lation reagents. The result is marketed as a healthier alternative to petroleum-based foams since petroleum-based foams give off [[volatile organic compounds]] as they age. In the marketing of products such as beds that include "natural" latex foams created with the Talalay process, these products are sometimes characterised as '[[Organic movement|organic]]' or as completely natural however there are different methods of producing Talalay that alter how natural the formula finishes. One compound called Styrene Butadyne Runner is a form of synthetic latex used by Talalay Global And is mixed with the latex from the hevea tree to form the final Talalay product. Vita Talalay in the Netherlands still produces a Talalay product that is free of Styrene Butadyne and uses the latex from the hevea tree and the entire base.
==Process== The process utilizes a closed mold with pre-vacuum, followed by freezing to maintain uniform bubble geometry. Carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) is flooded through the frozen, open foam matrix to form [[carbonic acid]] (CO<sub>2</sub>+H<sub>2</sub>O→ H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>). Much like the addition of [[sodium fluorosilicate]] (Na<sub>2</sub>SiF<sub>6</sub>) in the Dunlop process, the carbonic acid lowers the [[pH]], thereby causing gellation. In the next process step, [[vulcanization]] locks the foam into a uniform bubble distribution.
===Molding=== After the foamer aeration step, the compound is distributed into an opened mold in a precise volume and pattern. The Talalay type mold is designed to be closed and sealed with pressure provided by [[Hydraulic press|press hydraulics]]. After closing the mold, a vacuum is applied to the interior, thereby causing the air matrix bubbles to "inflate" and fill out the mold form.
===Freezing=== While being supported by the vacuum, the mold and foam mass temperature is reduced to −20 °F (−28 °C) and frozen in place. Because the resultant foam matrix is open, carbon dioxide can be pushed through the structure, thereby forming carbonic acid that moves the pH from above 10 to 7. The reduction in alkalinity triggers the foam to gel in place and hold its shape.
===Vulcanization=== The mold temperature can then be incrementally raised to the [[vulcanization]] temperature of 230 °F (115 °C) for a measured amount of time. At this point, the foam form can be de-molded and sent to a washing step. Typical molding cycles are 60 minutes. After washing, the foam form is introduced into the vulcanizer stage to complete the [[cross-link]]ing process. The final step is the drying process where residual moisture is driven off.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Rubber]]
